data.title: A brief history of naughty things appearing in kids’ TV
data.meta_description: A Netflix children's TV show has caused controversy recently due to the appearance of a rude image. But this is nothing new.
data.text:
There has been quite a furore surrounding cutesy Netflix children’s cartoon Maya the Bee.

The premise seems innocent enough. Sweet insect Maya leaves her hive to discover the world around her, educating kids on the beauty of nature along the way.

Recently however, Maya has been more naturist than naturalist.

A drawing of a penis was spotted in the background of a recent episode, leading to a wave of controversy.

Reportedly the work of a rogue artist, the incident – in an episode fittingly titled ‘King Willi’ – caused a number of outraged parents to condemn the show.

Yet the appearance of sexual innuendos and rude images in kids TV shows is nothing new.

In fact, it has been happening for as long as cartoons have been broadcast.

‘It starts with some sweets…’

Broadcast in Britain in the 1960s and 70s, clay-mation classic The Magic Roundabout featured more drug references than an episode of Breaking Bad.

The series, which originally ran on the BBC for 12 years, had copious underlying references to illicit substance use.

Excitable Dougal, a shaggy dog with boundless energy and an addiction to sugar cubes, famously claimed: “It starts with some sweets…and then you’re on two bags a day.”

His best friend Dylan, a rabbit who plays guitar and sleeps a lot, was assumed by many adults to be smoking pot off-camera.

Meanwhile, loveable cow Ermintrude was often seen chewing on a flower with a striking resemblance to an opiate poppy.

The five-minute storylines were ‘trippy’ to say the least.

In one iconic episode, Dougal attends a party he has no memory of, and proceeds to converse with a banana and a pear.

Seventies show Captain Pugwash supposedly employed dirty puns for character names: such as Seaman Stains and Master Bates. However, this is wholly an urban myth. Creator John Ryan successfully sued for damages after a newspaper printed the names as fact.

Cartoon Network and Nickelodeon led the way

For the connoisseur of inappropriate moments in kids’ shows, Cartoon Network’s output in the 1990s represents a veritable golden age of content.

An episode of Cow and Chicken famously caused controversy when a bunch of butch female motorcyclists turned up and began literally munching on a carpet.

Over on Nickelodeon, cult animation Ren & Stimpy was the subject of a number of bans and re-edits.

Chastised for being overly violent and boasting a number of references to alcoholism, it was controversial from the outset. One scene would be worthy of a place in horror franchise Saw.

Innuendo reached new heights when Stimpy was locked in a closet with Ren’s cousin, Sven.

“Hey this is private,” he says. Before shouting “I’m a sword swallower” from behind closed doors.

Taking it too far?

Rocko’s Modern Life, meanwhile, was a wallaby-starring cartoon rife with moments that were eventually pulled from broadcast.

In one episode, Rocko rents a room at the No Tell Motel, an inn with suspect sounds coming from behind each door.

In another, a jobless Rocko finds work as a phone sex operator.

For the most part, ‘inappropriate’ content in kids’ TV has typically taken the form of deliberate in-jokes from the writers and creatives.

However, as with Maya the Bee, occasionally somebody will sneak something into the background that was clearly not planned.

The offending episode has now been removed by Netflix. Creators Studio 100 have claimed the mishap “obviously results from a very bad joke from one of the 150 artists working on the production”.

With so many animators working on children’s shows at any one time, perhaps it’s surprising that these incidents don’t occur more often.
